ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the history of Indonesia!

I learned about the history of the Indonesia, from 650 AD to the present. I think that I took the most away from weeks about Indonesia after independence, including about the massacres of 1965-66 and East Timor.

Also interpretation of primary sources, analysis of textual and visual evidence.
I learned about the history of Indonesia and the islands, from the 700s to today. (Srivijaya and Majapahit Empires, colonization, World War II, Independence movement, post-Independence)
A comprehensive introductory education on the history of Indonesia, my family's origin country, which I never had the opportunity to formally learn about prior.
This course gave a comprehensive overview of Indonesian history and how to approach Southeast Asian studies from a historical lens.
I learned a broad overview of most of Indonesias history from ancient to modern, spanning from the Srivijaya to modern administrations.

This course was excellent for improving my writing, critical reading, analytical thinking, and historical thinking skills. I gained a lot of knowledge on Indonesian history and insights into thinking more like a historian.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very well-structured. You'll write 5 short response papers, a 5pg. response paper to an interesting movie, and 1 longer (~8-10pg.) paper about a topic of your choosing. The readings are really interesting and Prof. Yahaya is very knowledgeable about the material & the region.

Strengths: Dr. Yahaya is fantastic, and the readings are all excellent and fascinating. This is such a unique and special course that really has no substitutes among undergraduate offerings. The class is a lot of work, but has well-paced reading reflections and paper milestones such that you shouldn't be too bogged down by the end as long as you plan your time well.

Weaknesses: in some weeks, it would have been helpful to have more context in the readings about what exactly was happening in that time period; sometimes felt like the readings started off assuming that the reader had some background knowledge already (which was not true for most of us)

Strengths: class discussions were interesting, the film we watched was very eye-opening, liked the flexibility of the final paper, Professor Yahaya is very knowledgeable, class is very structured
Weaknesses: none really
There was a lot of lecturing during the 2 hour seminar.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes -- even if you know nothing about Indonesia (if that's the case, you'd probably benefit the most). Very well-taught class with tons of interesting material. Indonesia is fascinating, and it's super special that we have a whole course about it!
This is a great class if you are interested in Indonesia/Southeast Asia! I learned so much about its history
Yes! The readings were engaging and the assignments were fun! I entered the class with no background knowledge on Indonesia and felt like I gained a lot.
Yes, its pretty chill and you learn a lot
I would definitely recommend this course. The material is fascinating and the course is structured to make you a better historian and writer.
